text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
PractitionerRole Ipd-1: SHALL have contact information or a reference to an Endpoint
practitioner S1..1Reference(US Core Practitioner Profile)
organization S1..1Reference(US Core Organization Profile)
code S0..1CodeableConceptBinding: US Core Provider Role (NUCC) (extensible)
specialty S0..1CodeableConceptBinding: US Core Provider Speciality (NUCC) (extensible)
location S0..*Reference(US Core Location Profile)
telecom SI0..*ContactPoint
system S1..1code
value S1..1string
endpoint SI0..*

Documentation for this format

name: USCorePractitionerRoleProfile
title: US Core PractitionerRole Profile
description: The practitioner roles referenced in the US Core profiles.

element.short: Roles/organizations the practitioner is associated with
element.definition: This is basic constraint on PractitionerRole for use in US Core resources.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $contained in f:contained return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label
SHALL have contact information or a reference to an Endpoint

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).
element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Business Identifiers that are specific to a role/location
element.definition: Business Identifiers that are specific to a role/location.
element.requirements: Often, specific identities are assigned for the agent.

element.short: Whether this practitioner role record is in active use
element.definition: Whether this practitioner role record is in active use.
element.comment: If this value is false, you may refer to the period to see when the role was in active use. If there is no period specified, no inference can be made about when it was active.
element.requirements: Need to be able to mark a practitioner role record as not to be used because it was created in error, or otherwise no longer in active use.
element.meaningWhenMissing: This resource is generally assumed to be active if no value is provided for the active element

element.short: The period during which the practitioner is authorized to perform in these role(s)
element.definition: The period during which the person is authorized to act as a practitioner in these role(s) for the organization.
element.requirements: Even after the agencies is revoked, the fact that it existed must still be recorded.

mapping.map: (ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

element.short: Practitioner that is able to provide the defined services for the organization
element.definition: Practitioner that is able to provide the defined services for the organization.

element.short: Organization where the roles are available
element.definition: The organization where the Practitioner performs the roles associated.

element.short: Roles which this practitioner may perform
element.definition: Roles which this practitioner is authorized to perform for the organization.
element.comment: A person may have more than one role.
element.requirements: Need to know what authority the practitioner has - what can they do?

binding.description: Provider role codes consisting of NUCC Health Care Provider Taxonomy Code Set for providers.

mapping.map: PRD-1 / STF-18  / PRA-3  / PRT-4  / ROL-3 / ORC-12 / OBR-16 / PV1-7 / PV1-8 / PV1-9 / PV1-17
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

element.short: Specific specialty of the practitioner
element.definition: Specific specialty of the practitioner.

binding.description: Provider specialty codes consist of NUCC Health Care Provider Taxonomy Code Set for providers.

element.short: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care
element.definition: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care.

mapping.map:
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)
However these are accessed via the Site.ServiceSite.ServiceSiteProvider record. (The Site has the location)

element.short: The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s)
element.definition: The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s).

element.short: Contact details that are specific to the role/location/service
element.definition: Contact details that are specific to the role/location/service.
element.requirements: Often practitioners have a dedicated line for each location (or service) that they work at, and need to be able to define separate contact details for each of these.

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: phone | fax | email | pager | url | sms | other
element.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.

element.short: The actual contact point details
element.definition: The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
element.comment: Additional text data such as phone extension numbers, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.
element.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.

element.short: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc.for a current/permanent one

mapping.map: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

element.short: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)
element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. ContactPoints with lower rank values are more preferred than those with higher rank values.
element.comment: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

element.short: Time period when the contact point was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.

element.short: Times the Service Site is available
element.definition: A collection of times the practitioner is available or performing this role at the location and/or healthcareservice.
element.comment: More detailed availability information may be provided in associated Schedule/Slot resources.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. element.short: mon | tue | wed | thu | fri | sat | sun
element.definition: Indicates which days of the week are available between the start and end Times.

element.short: Always available? e.g. 24 hour service
element.definition: Is this always available? (hence times are irrelevant) e.g. 24 hour service.

element.short: Opening time of day (ignored if allDay = true)
element.definition: The opening time of day. Note: If the AllDay flag is set, then this time is ignored.
element.comment: The timezone is expected to be for where this HealthcareService is provided at.

element.short: Closing time of day (ignored if allDay = true)
element.definition: The closing time of day. Note: If the AllDay flag is set, then this time is ignored.
element.comment: The timezone is expected to be for where this HealthcareService is provided at.

element.short: Not available during this time due to provided reason
element.definition: The practitioner is not available or performing this role during this period of time due to the provided reason.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. element.short: Reason presented to the user explaining why time not available
element.definition: The reason that can be presented to the user as to why this time is not available.

element.short: Service not available from this date
element.definition: Service is not available (seasonally or for a public holiday) from this date.

element.short: Description of availability exceptions
element.definition: A description of site availability exceptions, e.g. public holiday availability. Succinctly describing all possible exceptions to normal site availability as details in the available Times and not available Times.

element.short: Technical endpoints providing access to services operated for the practitioner with this role
element.definition: Technical endpoints providing access to services operated for the practitioner with this role.
element.requirements: Organizations have multiple systems that provide various services and ,ay also be different for practitioners too.So the endpoint satisfies the need to be able to define the technical connection details for how to connect to them, and for what purpose.

element.definition: This is basic constraint on PractitionerRole for use in US Core resources.

constraint.human: SHALL have contact information or a reference to an Endpoint

binding.description: Provider role codes consisting of NUCC Health Care Provider Taxonomy Code Set for providers.
Provider specialty codes consist of NUCC Health Care Provider Taxonomy Code Set for providers.
